title: 114_hr2568
content:
The "Fair Medical Audits Act of 2015" includes provisions for transparency in the audit process, qualifications of auditors, recoupments, extrapolation, payment for supporting documentation, notice of code over-utilization, and a change in look back period. The "Fair Medical Audits Act of 2015" mandates that healthcare providers must be given specific information by contractors conducting audits, including auditor details, audit legal authority, designated records, submission deadlines, and record submission address. The "Fair Medical Audits Act of 2015" requires healthcare providers to receive detailed information from audit contractors, including errors found, identification of underpayments, and calculation of overpayment amounts. SEC. 3. QUALIFICATIONS OF AUDITORS. Section 1893(h)(6) of the Social Security Act is amended to include qualifications for individuals conducting medical necessity reviews, such as knowledge of ICD, CPT, and HCPCS codes, medical record formats, and licensure in a relevant clinical discipline. This includes requiring a doctor of medicine or osteopathy of the same specialty and subspecialty for medical necessity reviews of physician records. The amendment to Section 1893(h)(6) of the Social Security Act includes qualifications for individuals conducting medical necessity reviews. This involves knowledge of codes, medical record formats, and licensure in a relevant clinical discipline. Additionally, contractors with a certain percentage of overpayment determinations overturned by an Administrative Law Judge may face penalties. Contractors are also liable for paying providers' attorneys' fees for overpayment determinations double the final amount. The amendment allows for penalties on contractors with a high rate of overturned overpayment determinations. Penalties collected can be used for incentive payments to Medicare contractors for improper payment outreach and education programs. SEC. 4. RECOUPMENTS amended to specify return of recoupments if decision is reversed on appeal. Effective for recoupments after enactment. SEC. 5. EXTRAPOLATION. Amends Section 1893(f)(3) of the Social Security Act to specify conditions for using extrapolation in determining overpayments. Effective for determinations made after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 6. Payment for supporting documentation: Contractors must reimburse providers for production costs at rates set by the Secretary. 

SEC. 7. Notice of over-utilization of codes: Contractors must give a 90-day notice before initiating audits, documentation requests, or recoupments for identified over-utilized codes.

SEC. 8. Change in look back period. SEC. 8. CHANGE IN LOOK BACK PERIOD. Amends the Social Security Act to reduce the look back period from 4 fiscal years to 2 fiscal years. SEC. 9. GENERAL EFFECTIVE DATE. The amendments apply to contracts entered into or renewed after the enactment of this Act.
